msContents.textLang: Middle English, South Worcestershire dialect (Simon Horobin, The Language of the Chaucer Tradition, pp. 147–8); with some Latin

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Canterbury Tales
msItem.incipit:
Whan that april with his showres swote
The drouth of March hath perced the rote
msItem.explicit:
In which into þis day in noble wyse
Men don to Crist and to his seint seruise
msItem.note: Ends with the Second Nun’s Tale.

msItem.title: The General Prologue
msItem.incipit:
Whan that april with his showres swote
The drouth of March hath perced the rote
msItem.explicit:
And by gan with right a mery chere
His tale a noon and seide as þe may here

msItem.title: The Knight’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Hic incipit fabula Militis
msItem.incipit:
Whilom was as olde stories tellen vs
Ther was a duk þat hight Teseus
msItem.explicit:
Thus endeth palamon and emelye
And god save al þis feire companye

msItem.title: The ‘Knight-Miller link’
msItem.rubric: Hic incipit prohemium fabule molendinarij
msItem.incipit:
Whan þat the knight hadde þis his tale tolde
In al þe companye nas þer yonge ne olde
msItem.explicit:
Avyseth you and put me out of blame
And eek men shal not make ernest of game

msItem.title: The Miller’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
As brode as is þe boos of a bokelyr
Hir shoes were laced vpon hir legges hye
msItem.explicit:
And Nicholas was skalded in þe towte
Þis tale is don god save al þe rowte
msItem.finalRubric: Here eneth þe Millers tale

msItem.title: The Reeve’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And begynneth þe prologe of þe Reues tale
msItem.incipit:
Whan folke han laughen at þis nyce cas
Of Absolon and hende Nichola
msItem.explicit:
He kan wel in myn ye seen a stalke
But in his owne he ne kan seen a balke

msItem.title: The Reeve’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth the Reues tale
msItem.incipit:
At Trompyngton nat ferre fro cantebrigge
Ther goth a brok and over þat a brygge
msItem.explicit:
Save al þis company grete and smale
Thus have y quyt þe Miller in my tale
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Reues tale

msItem.title: The Cook’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth the prolage of þe Cookes tale
msItem.incipit:
The Coke of london while þe Reve spake
ffor Ioy him þought he claued him on his bake
msItem.explicit:
And ther with al he lough and made cheere
And seyd his tale as ye shal after heere

msItem.title: The Cook’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth the Cookes tale
msItem.incipit:
A prentys whilom dwelled in oure sitee
And of a crafte of vitallers was he
msItem.explicit:
A wife he hadde that helde her contenaunce
A shoppe and ever sche pleyed for his sustenaunce
What thorowe hym selfe and his felawe þat sought
Vnto a myschefe bothe þey were broght
The tone y dampned to preson perpetually
The tother to deth for he couthe not of clergye
And therfore yonge men lerne while ye may
That with mony dyvers thoghtes beth prycked al þe day
Remembre you what myschefe cometh of mysgouernaunce
Thus mowe ye lerne worschep and come to substaunce
Thenke how grace and governaunce hath broght hem a boune
Many pore mannys son chese state of þe towne
Euer rewle the after þe beste man of name
And god may grace þe to come to þe same
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Cokes tale
msItem.note: Forty-five alliterating couplets are added throughout the text, including the twelve final lines transcribed above: six lines following I.4382; eight lines following 4388; two lines following 4390; six lines following 4398; four lines following 4410; and four lines following 4412.

msItem.title: The Introduction to the Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Here folowen the wordes of the hoost vnto the man of lawe
msItem.incipit:
Oure host saugh wel þat þe bryght sonne
þe ark of his artificial day hath y ronne
msItem.explicit:
I speke in prose and let hym rymes make
And with þat word he with a sory chere
Bygan his tale as ye may after here
msItem.finalRubric: Here enden the words of the hoost vnto the man of lawe

msItem.title: The Man of Law’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth the prologe of the tale of the man of lawe
msItem.incipit:
O hateful harme condicioun of povert
With thurst with cold with hunger so confounded
msItem.explicit:
Nere þat a Marchaunt gon is many a yere
Me taught a tale which þat ye shal here

msItem.title: The Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþ þe tale of þe man of lawe
msItem.incipit:
In surrie whilome dwelt a compaigny
Of chapman riche & therto sadde and trewe
msItem.explicit:
Ioy after wo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs all þat byn in this place
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tale of Custaunce

msItem.title: The Wife of Bath’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþ þe prologe of þe wife of Bathe
msItem.incipit:
Experience thogh non auctorite
Were in þis worlde is right y now for me
msItem.explicit:
If I have licence of þis worthi frere
Yis dame quod he telle forth and I wol heere
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prolage of the wyfe of Bathe

msItem.title: The Wife of Bath’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth her tale
msItem.incipit:
In the olde dayes of Kyng arthoure
Of which þat Britons speke grete honoure
msItem.explicit:
And olde and angry nygardys of dispence
God sende hem sone verray pestellence
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Wyfes tale of Bathe

msItem.title: The Friar’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth þe prologe of þe freris tale
msItem.incipit:
This worthi lymytour this noble frere
He made al wey a lowryng chere
msItem.explicit:
And after þis he seide vnto þe ffrere
Tel forth youre tale leve maister deere
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prologe of the ffreres tale

msItem.title: The Friar’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth hys tale
msItem.incipit:
Whilome ther was dwellyng in my contre
An Erchdeken a man of high degre
msItem.explicit:
And prayeth þat thes sumpnours hem repente
Of her misdedis er þat the fende hem hente
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the ffreres tale

msItem.title: The Sommoner’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth the Somnours tale
msItem.incipit:
This somnoure n his storopes high he stode
Vpon þis frere his hert was so wodde
msItem.explicit:
God save you alle save þis cursed frere
My prologe wol y ende in þis manere
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the prolage of the Somnours tale

msItem.title: The Summoner’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And begynneþ his tale
msItem.incipit:
Lordings þer is in yorkeshire as y gesse
A mershcontre called holdernesse
msItem.explicit:
And Iankin hath ywonne a new gowne
My tale is don we ben almost at toune
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Somnours tale

msItem.title: The Clerk’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And begynneþ þe prohemium of þe clerke of Oxonforddes Tale
msItem.incipit:
Sir clerk of Oxenforde oure host seyde
ye ride as koy and stylle as doth a Mayde
msItem.explicit:
Save þat he wol conueyen his matere
But this his tale which þat ye may here

msItem.title: The Clerk’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
Ther is at þe west syde of ytaille
Doun at þe rote of vesulus þe colde
msItem.explicit:
Be ay of chere as light as lefe on lynde
And late him care and wepe and wrynge and wayle

msItem.title: The ‘Clerk’s Endlink’/‘The Host’s Stanza’
msItem.quote:
This worthi clerke whan ended was his tale
Oure host seide and swore by goddes bones
Me were lever than a barel ale
My wife at home hedde harde þis legende ones
This is a gentile tale for þe nones
As to my purpose wist ye my wille
But thing þat wol nat be lete it be stille
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the tale of the Clerke of Oxenforde

msItem.title: The Merchant’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth the prologe of þe Merchantz tale
msItem.incipit:
Wepyng and waillyng care and oþer sorow
I koow you on eve and on morow
msItem.explicit:
Gladly quod he but of myne owne sore
ffor sory herte I telle may namore
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe prologe of þe Merchantes

msItem.title: The Merchant’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth hys tale
msItem.incipit:
Whilom þer was dwellyng in lumbardy
A worthy knyght þat boren was of payuy
msItem.explicit:
Thus endeth here my tale of Ianuarye
God blesse vs and his moder seynt marie
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Merchaunts tale of Ianuarie
msItem.note: IV.2280 omitted; 2288 follows 2279 and recurs in its proper place.

msItem.title: The ‘Merchant’s Endlink’
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth þe prologe of þe Squyers tale
msItem.incipit:
Ey goddes mercy seide oure hoost þo
Now such a wyf y prey god kepe me fro
msItem.explicit:
And eke my witte suffiseth not þer to
To tellen alle wherefor my tale is do

msItem.title: The ‘Squire’s Headlink’
msItem.incipit:
Squyer come nere yf it youre wylle be
And sey somwhat of love for certes ye
msItem.explicit:
Haue me excused yef y speke amysse
My wille is good and lo my tale is this
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe prologe of þe Squyers tale

msItem.title: The Squire’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth hys tale ffulle
msItem.incipit:
At Sarry in the londe of Tartarye
Ther dwelled a kyng that werryed Russie
msItem.explicit:
And after wol y speke of kambalo
That faught in lystes with þe brethren two

msItem.title: The Franklin’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
And forto lede þe more in blisse hir lyves
Of his fre wille he swore hir as a knyght
msItem.explicit:
Now telleth me er þat ye ferther wende
I kan namore my tale is at an ende
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the ffrankeleyns tale
msItem.note: V.709–28 (Prologue), 726–43 lost; 1013, 1455–6. 1493–8, omitted; 1286–9 inserted at foot.

msItem.title: The Physician’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here after begynneth the Phisiciens tale
msItem.incipit:
Ther was as telleth Thitus liuius
A knyght þat called was virginius
msItem.explicit:
þer fore y rede you þis counsel take
fforsaketh synne er synne you forsake
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Phisiciens tale

msItem.title: The ‘Host’s Words’/‘Physician-Pardoner Link’
msItem.rubric: And begynneth þe mery talkyng of þe hoost to þe Phisicien and þe pardoner
msItem.incipit:
Owre hoost gan to swere as he were wode
harrow quod he by nailes and by blode
msItem.explicit:
I graunte I wyis quod he but y mote þinke
Vpon somme honeste þing while y drynke

msItem.title: The Pardoner’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth the Prologe of þe pardoners tale
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas ad Timotheum 6º
msItem.incipit:
Lordinges quod he in chirche whenne y preche
I peyne me to han an hauten speche
msItem.explicit:
Which y am wonte to preche for to wynne
Now holde youre pees my tale y wol bygynne
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prologe of the Perdoners tale

msItem.title: The Pardoner’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth his tale
msItem.incipit:
In flaundres whilome was a compaignye
Of yonge folke þat hauntedden folye
msItem.explicit:
And as we deden lete vs lagh and pley
Anon they kiste and riden forth hir wey
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Perdoners tale
msItem.note: VI.669 omitted; spurious line inserted at foot to follow 670.

msItem.title: The Shipman’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And begynneth þe Shipmannes tale
msItem.incipit:
A marchant whilome dwelled at seint Denys
þat riche was for which men hilde him wys
msItem.explicit:
þus endeth my tale and god vs sende
Taylyng ynow vnto oure lyves ende
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Shypmannes tale

msItem.title: The ‘Shipman-Prioress Link’
msItem.rubric: Herken þe now the mery wordes of the hoost
msItem.incipit:
Wel seyd by corpus dominus quod oure host
Now longe mote þou sayle by þe coost
msItem.explicit:
And next if so were þat ye wolde
Gladly quod she and seyde as ye shal here

msItem.title: The Prioress’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth the prohemium of the Prioresse tale
msItem.incipit:
O lorde o lorde þy name how meruelous
Is in this large worlde ysparde quod she
msItem.explicit:
Right so fare I and þerfore y you pray
Gydeth my songe þat I of you shal sey
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the prohemium

msItem.title: The Prioress’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And here begynneth the pryores tale of Alma redemptoris mater
msItem.incipit:
Ther was in asye in a grete citee
Amonges Cristen folke in Iuerye
msItem.explicit:
On vs his grete merci multiplye
ffor reuerence of his moder Marye Amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the pryoresse tale

msItem.title: The Prologue to Sir Thopas
msItem.rubric: Behold the mery talking of þe hoost to þe Chaucer
msItem.incipit:
When seide was al þis miracle euery man
As sobre was þat wonder was to see
msItem.explicit:
ye þat is gode quod he now shal we here
Some deynte þing me thinketh by his chere

msItem.title: The Sir Thopas
msItem.rubric: Nexte foloweþ Chaucers tale of Thopas And here begynneth his tale
msItem.incipit:
Listenneth lordynges in gode entent
And y wol telle verement
msItem.explicit:
As dide þe knyght ser percyvelle
So worthi vnder wede
Tyl on a day

msItem.title: The ‘Thopas-Melibee Link’
msItem.rubric: Here the hoost stynteth Chaucer of his tale of Thopas And biddeth hym telle a nother tale
msItem.incipit:
Namore of þis for goddes dignite
Quod oure host for þou makest me
msItem.explicit:
After þe whiche þis myry tale y write
And þerfore herkeneth what y shal you sey
And lete me tellen as my tale y prey
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth Chaucers tale
msItem.note: Two spurious lines follow VII.966 introducing Manciple’s Tale.

msItem.title: The Manciple’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And begynneþ A lytel Tretis of þe Crowe
msItem.incipit:
When phebus dwelt in þis worlde a doun
As olde bokes maken mencioun
msItem.explicit:
Where so euer þou come among high or lowe
Kepe wel þi tonge and þinke wel on þe crowe
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tale of þe Crowe

msItem.title: The Prologue of the Second Nun’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
The ministre and þe norice vnto vices
Which þat men clepe in englissh ydlenesse
msItem.explicit:
And brennynge euer in cherite ful briȝht
Now have y you declared what she hight
msItem.finalRubric: And here begynneth þe Nonnes tale

msItem.title: The Second Nun’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
Þis mayden bright Cecilie as hir lyfe seith
Was comen of Romains and of noble kynde
msItem.explicit:
In which into þis day in noble wyse
Men don to Crist and to his seint seruise
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Nonnes tale of the storye of the blessed lyfe and Martirdome of the glorious virgine and Martir seynte Cecile translated in to englysshe tonge

msItem.title: Poems by or ascribed to John Lydgate

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Verses on the Kings of England
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþ a lytel Tretis made and compyled in Balade be Dan Iohn Lydgate Monke of Bury of al the kynges þat hath regned sethen Wyllian Conquerour
msItem.incipit:
This mighti William duke of normandie
As bokes olde maketh mencioun
msItem.explicit:
Now lord send hym siche gouernaunce
Long to reioyse & reigne in his ryght
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tretis of alle the kynges whiche hath regned in this lande sethen þe tyme of William the Conquerour

msItem.author: John Lydgate (attrib.)
msItem.title: Stans puer ad mensam
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth the godely tretis of þe Norture atte þe table compiled in Balade be Dan Iohn Lydegate. Monke of Bury
msItem.incipit:
My dere sonne first þi selfe enhable
With þyn hert to vertuous disciplyne
msItem.explicit:
If ought be amys in worde sillable or dede
Put al þe defaute vpon Iohn lidgate

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Dietary
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth a neodful Tretis for mannes helthe of his body compiled and made compen in Balade be Dan Iohn lydgate Monke of Bury
msItem.incipit:
For helth of body kover for colde þin hede
Ete no rawe mete take gode hede herto
msItem.explicit:
Of maister Antony nor of maister hugh
To all indifferent Rihest dietarie

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Riȝt as the crabbe goth forward
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþ þe Tretis of þe Crabbe
msItem.incipit:
This worlde is ful of stableness
Ther is þer inne no variaunce
msItem.explicit:
þe heuenly signe maketh demonstraunce
Right as þe Crab goth forewarde
msItem.finalRubric: Hererendeth þe tresi of þe Crabbe

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Rammeshorne
msItem.rubric: And begynneþ a tretis of þe rammeshorne
msItem.incipit:
Al rightwesnesse doth now procede
Sitte crowned lich an Emperesse
msItem.explicit:
þus eche estate is gouerned in sothnesse
Conueyed by lyue right as arammes horne
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth a sotil compiled reson of þe Crabbe

msItem.author: John Lydgate (attrib.)
msItem.title: A wikked tong wol alway deme amis
msItem.rubric: And here begynneþ a resoun de fallacia mundi
msItem.incipit:
Considere wel with euery circumstaunce
Of what estate euer þat þou be
msItem.explicit:
Chastiseth þe revers and of wysdom doth þis
Voydeth youre heryng from al þat sey amys

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Life of St Margaret
msItem.rubric: Here begynneth þe prologe of þe holy seynt seyn Margarete compendiously compiled in balade by lydgate Dan Iohn Monke of Bury. Anno viii henr viᵗⁱ

msItem.incipit:
At the reuerence of seint margarete
My purpos is hir lyf to compile
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe prologe of Seynt Margarete

msItem.rubric: And nexte folowyng begynneth hir storye
msItem.explicit:
Til atte last in vertu complet gode
ffor cristes sake she shedde hir herte blode
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe life of seynte Margarete

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Legend of St. George
msItem.rubric: And begynneth þe lyfe of the glorious martir seint George
msItem.incipit:
S ye folkes þat here present be
Which of þis story shal haue inspeccoun
msItem.note: The opening illuminated initial provides S for O.
msItem.explicit:
Was brennt vnwarly by consumpsioun
As he repeired home to his mansioun
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the lyfe of seynt George.

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fifteen Joys and Sorrows of Our Lady

msItem.rubric: And here begynneth þe prologe of þe xv Ioyes of our ladye
msItem.incipit:
Be twene mydnyght and þe fressh morowe grey
Nat longe agon in herte ful pensife
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeþ þe prolog of þe xv Ioyes & begyneþ þe tale

msItem.explicit:
To þat entent ydo the forth directe
Where þu failest þat men shal þe correcte
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the xv heuynes of oure lady

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Dance of Macabre
msItem.rubric: Here begynneþ a tretis of the daunce of Poulys otherweyes called Makabre
msItem.incipit:
Hec scriptura deus pompam luxumque relegat
Inque choris nostris ducere festa monet
Creatures ye þat be resonable
The life desiryng whiche is eternal
msItem.explicit:
Sit Iugiter cuncti sapientes vinere certent
Vt velut inferni sit metuenda palus
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth a tretis of the daunce of Poules otherweyes called Makabre

supportDesc.collation: 1-58 (fols. 1-40), 68–1 (fols. 41-47; 1st excised), 7–178 (fols. 48-135), 188–1 (fols. 136-142; 3rd excised), 19–268 (fols. 143–207), 278–1 (fols. 208-214; 8th excised), 286–3 (fols. 215-217; 3rd, 4th, 6th excised, with two stubs between fols. 216/217, one following fol. 217). Cathwords framed in scrolls at the right foot of final leaves of quires. Quire signtures: a–z, followed by abbreviations for &, con, est, and the words est and amen.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in violet ink, 39–40 long lines, ruled space 245 110

handDesc.handNote: Gothic cursiva antiquior: Late Medieval English Scribes understands it as the work of a single scribe working over a period of time, but Manly/Rickert, The Text of the Canterbury Tales (1940), 1:64–70 suggest it should be understood as the work of three scribes, at fols. 1–96, 96–167, and 167–end.

decoDesc.decoNote: Historiated initial depicting Chaucer or another pilgrim, fol. 1r, with acanthus scrolls displaying gilded inscriptions, Pencer de may pencer de may, Ihesu Marri ladi help, In God is al mi trust in God, As fortune fausit as fortune fausit (Cf. Pächt and Alexander iii. 890, pl. LXXXV.)
Tales, prologues, and links open with filigree borders.
Rubrics, paraphs, and running heads in red, using blue as an alternating colour. Versals shaded with a yellow wash.

binding.p: Brown tanned calf over laminated pulpboard.

history.provenance: Possibly made for the Beauchamp family, earls of Warwick. Kathleen Scott, Later Gothic Manuscripts (London, 1996), 2:250, suggests that the historiated initial on fol. 1r and borders is by an illuminator that also contributed to New York, Morgan Library and Museum, MS M.893, which she believes to have been made in London in the 1430s or early 1440s. Manly-Rickert, 1:69-70 further note a fifteenth-century drypoint inscription, Belyham, Belchiam, or Belthiam (head of fol. 139r), which they suggest is a form of the Beauchamp name.
Inscribed in red crayon, Iho (fol. 21r), fifteenth century; Memorandum that Ihon (fol. 217v).
Inscribed in drypoint, gryfyn (fol. 6r), fifteenth century.

Inscribed, Thomas Smythe the hathe and his lovyng ffrend no Willm s (fol. 173r), sixteenth century. Manly-Rickert, 1:69 note marriages between the families of Sir John Smythe (d. 1547) and Edward Griffin (d. 1569). Not the same hand as My well beloyed frynd (fol. 152r), sixteenth century.

George Upton (d. 1608/9), MP for Wells: inscribed, This is George Vpton His book (fol. 55r, written vertically along the fore-edge). His wife, Frances Upton, inscribed Frauncis Vpton (fol. 106r). A George Upton is listed as a Bodleian benefactor, having donated four pounds to library before 1601.
history.acquisition: Likely acquired in 1618–20; first appears in the 1620 catalogue, C.7.11. Former shelfmark Bod. 660 (fol. 1r).
